cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
Steamers leave Suez every Thursday at 5 p.m. for JEDDAH,calling a required a TOR (for Monni-Ninal) and YAMBO, and containing in alternate weeks to SUAKIM, MASSOWAH, HODMIDAH,and ADXN. .
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.
Alexandria-Patras-Brindisi-Trieste Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 10 and 24 October, 7 and 21 November, 5 and 19 December.
East Line.
Steamer leaves Alexandria on or about 8 and 22 October, 5 and 19 November, 3, 17 and 31 December.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

div.head: Sanita's
div.p: As an Unqualled Purifying Agent and is Indispensable in Hot Countries
"Sanitas" Disinfecting Fluid

is non-poisonous and non-staining, and for general or personal use is thoroughly effective. It completely disinfects the house in which it is used, and, administered internally prevents Cholera, Typhoid Fever, Dysentery, etc.
"Sanitas" Disenfecting Power
is the best air purifier known, and a stronger antiseptic and deodorant than carbolic acid, besides being pleasant and refreshing.
"Sanitas" Eucalyptus Soap
is specifically recommended by the medical faculty for use in hot climates, because of its fine distinfecting qualities and its fragrances
Kingzett's Fumigating Candles
supply the safest and most convenient means of sulphur fumigation. For the disinfection of infected places, bedding, clothing, etc., they are both efficious and economical. Destroy all insects.
The "Sanitas" Co. LTD. BETHNAL GREEN, LONDON, K.

div.head: REMARKS.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber's address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.O.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette

Price: One Piastre Tariff.
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 28, 1904.

div.head: THE RUSSIAN BLUNDER
div.p: The feeling at home in regard to the North Sea incident, we are told this morning, is at fever heat, and all political parties are united in demanding full reparation for the lives of the fishermen. The decision of the Cabinet Council at this morning's meeting will be awaited with the most extreme anxiety. The telegrams from Gibraltar and Malta show that everything is being made ready for the terrible eventuality of the outbreak of hostilities. The excuses offered for the outrage by Admiral Rodjestvensky, in command of the Baltic Fleet, and by Prince Keretelli, of the Imperator Alex ander, as given in our telegrams of yesterday and to-day, are utterly unintelligible. The

Admiral announces in an interview, published in a Madrid newspaper, that, before leaving Libau, he had declared his intention of attack- ing any ship approaching his fleet. This statement is absurd as no trawler can be con- sidered as coming within the category of a vessel likely to attack the Baltic fleet. Trawl- ers, as a rule, steam at the rate of eight knots an hour at their most rapid speed. When in the immediate neighbourhood of the nets on the North Sea fishing grounds the trawlers are either at anchor or heaving in their cable for trawling purposes. But to an ordinary sea- faring man it is well understood that all ships, when prudent, have to keep clear of trawlers, when either at steam or at sail, owing to the fact that this class of vessels are forced to be either permanently or temporarily at anchor. The allegation of Prince Keretelli, which might be construed to the effect that it was possible to mistake a steam trawler for a torpedo-boat, is ludicrous in the extreme. A steam trawler can no more be mistaken for a torpedo-boat than can a dahabieh be mistaken for a first-class battleship. The contour of these two classes of vessels is utterly dissimilar, for a steam trawler is a broad-bottomed boat with a funnel and lights accordingly, while a torpedo-boat is, as a rule, a wedge shaped vessel, of a most abnor- mal, and consequently easily distinguishable, type. The torpedo-boat lies low in the water, while the trawler floats on the bosom of the ocean. The most ignorant landsmen, whose knowledge of ships is only derived from the illustrated papers, could tell the difference between these two classes of vessels.

Another extraordinary statement made by Prince Keretelli is that the trawlers were signalled to state their nationality. He goes on to say that they refused to comply and advanced among the battleships. This is absurd, because a trawler should, whether steam or sail, be well known to any qualified naval or mer- cantile officer. Moreover, it is quite easy to make out the nationality of a trawler by the indications of the fishing grounds. Conse-quently, trawlers do not exhibit signals of nationality, save and except those signals enforced by the Board of Trade. Again, it is not even obligatory, nor is it customary, on a trawler to fly a distinguishing national flag either by day or by night. In fact, no vessel can make known its nationality at night, except, for example, the first-class liners, who have their own private codes of signals for the pur- pose, which are well known to all signal stations. But a trawler has no such facilities because there is never any need for these vessels to make their nationality known either by night or by day, as fishing boats are as a general, rule confined to their own fishing grounds and do not move beyond them. The Prince goes on to declare that the report of a gun was heard, and that thereupon the Russian Admiral ordered his vessels at once to form in line of battle and reply to the fire. This also is ridiculous for trawlers do not carry guns except for use as a signal of distress. The report, which preyed on the excitable nerves of the terrified Russians, may possibly have been the detonation of a discharge of dynamite. Trawl- ers are not permitted to, but sometimes do, make use of dynamite in order to kill fish for a better haul. The trawlers hurl the detonator into the water and an explosion follows, but no naval officer could, under any circumstances, mistake such an action for the discharge of a cannon. Even if we assume that the Russians were so stupid as to make such a childish mistake, why then did they sail away without endeavouring to sink these "torpedo-boats" or save the lives of those on board the vessels they had attacked? We need not, however, attempt to continue our analysis of these excuses, for they are evidently made solely in order to hide a most gross error of judgment, induced by sheer nervousness. But this is no excuse in the case of the commander of a fleet, who should be selected for the post in virtue of the soundness of his judgment. The fact that the Admiral believed that Japanese torpedo vessels were infesting the North Sea, 6,000 miles from the seat of war, shows either that he had not a particle of confidence in his Intelligence Department, or that he has been reduced to such a state of tension owing to the Japanese victories, that he has lost even the remnants of that courage and clear-headedness which seamanship always demands as its primary qualifications.
WINDSOR HOTEL.
Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea. Central position. Under English management,
TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS
NORTH SEA OUTRAGE.
FEELING AT FEVER HEAT.
ALL PARTIES UNITED.
OMINOUS NAVAL ORDERS.

LONDON, October 27. The feeling in England is at fever heat. All parties are absolutely united in insisting upon full reparation. Lord Rosebery and Si H. Campbell Bannerman have publicly, declar ed that they will support the movement.
The view in official circles here is that it is imperative that a satisfactory settlement should be arranged before the Baltic fleet reaches a certain point on its outward voyage. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, October 27. Admiral Rodjestvensky's official report has reached here. He says that two torpedo-boats were among the trawlers. The Admiral deplores the loss of life.
Negotiations are still proceeding. There is reason to believe that no ultimatum has been presented by Great Britain, who has not gone beyond pressing for a definite reply.

The opinion in Russian official circles is that England's impatience is not justified, in view of the difficulty of the circumstances. It is suggested that the explanations of Admiral Rodjestvensky, which have been transmitted to the British Embassy, should form the subject of a joint enquiry. (Reuter.)
GIBRALTAR, October 27.
The Channel fleet is ready for sea at a moment's notice.
LONDON, October 27.
The Cabinet has been summoned for tomorrow.
MALTA, October 27.

H.M.'s battleship Queen and 9 destroyers have sailed from here for an unknown destina- tion. A division of the Mediterranean Fleet, now at Fiume, has received urgent orders to unite with the division which is at present at Pola, and to proceed westwards.
GIBRALTAR, October 28.
The Channel Fleet, which cleared for action yesterday, sails to-day, ostensibly for a sham
attack on the Rock.
(Reuter.)
LONDON, October 28.
The two divisions of the Mediterranean Fleet, which are respectively at Pola and Fiume, have sailed, it is believed, for Gibraltar. (Reuter.)
RUSSIAN ADMIRAL'S REPORT
THE TORPEDO ATTACK.
SYMPATHY FOR VICTIMS.
ST. PETERSBURG, October 27.

Admiral Rodjestvensky. has telegraphed, concerning the North Sea incident, that two strange torpedo-boats were amongst the fishing boats. He expresses his regret at the death of the English fishermen.
Spain has authorised the Russian vessels to take on 400 tons of coal each. (Havas.)

ST. PETERSBURG, October 28. (Official). Two telegrams have been received from Admiral Rodjestvensky. The first one declares that two torpedo-boats, with no lights showing, attacked the leading vessel of the fleet. The latter then swept the sea with her searchlights, and opened fire, whereupon the presence of several small steamers, resembling fishing vessels, was discovered. The fleet endeavoured to spare the latter, as soon as the torpedo boats disappeared.

The Admiral declares that no torpedo-boats accompanied his fleet. One of the strange torpedo-boats was sunk. The other, being only slightly damaged, remained till morning near the small steamers. The fleet did not assist the latter because, in view of their obstinacy in crossing the Russian line, they were suspect- ed of complicity in the attack. Several of the fishing vessels showed no lights, and the re- mainder only put them out very late.

The second telegram stated that the fleet met fishing boats to the number of several hundreds, and showed them every considera- tion, except where they were in company with foreign torpedo-boats. The Admiral went on to say "If there were also on the scene of the occurrence fishermen who were imprudently involved in this enterprise, I beg, on behalf of the fleet, to express my sincere regret for the unfortunate victims of circumstances under which no warship could have acted otherwise, even in time of profound peace." (Reuter.)
NORWEGIAN SHIP FIRED ON.
PARIS, October 27.
A Norwegian ship was fired upon by the Russians in the English Channel on the 23rd t inst. Firing ceased as soon as the ship hoisted a ber ensign, (Havas.)
FLEET EN ROUTE FOR TANGIER
A NAVAL COUNCIL.
VIGO, October 28.

The Baltic Fleet is expected to leave her for Tangier to-day. Each vessel has been per mitted to take 400 tons of coal. All yesterday afternoon the Russian Consul conferred with Admiral Rodjestvensky on board the flagship The Admiral subsequently summoned the captains, and had a long consultation with them. (Reuter.)
THE WAR.
RUSSIAN ATTACK.
MUKDEN, October 27.
An artillery duel took place last night on the north bank of the Sha-Ho. The Russianswere attacking.
(Reuter)
LOCAL AND GENERAL
EXILES.-Three "undesirable" Greeks are to be repatriated by the Hellenic consular authorities on the first ship leaving for Greece.
"AT HOME-The "at home" to be given by Canon and Mrs. Ward will take place on Tuesday next, and not on Sunday, as announ ced yesterday.
FIELD
OPERATIONS. The 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment was exercised this morning in field operations in the direction of Sidi Bishr, under the supervision of the Brigadier General Commanding.

THE NEW ENGLISH JUDGES-It has been stated in the local Press that the three new English judges are to be appointed to the native courts at Zagazig, Assiout, and Beni Souef. No decision on the subject, however, has as yet been arrived at.

H. M.'S GARRISON CHURCH OF ST. GEORGE. The Right Rev. Bishop Morley, D.D., Arch- deacon of Egypt, will preach at the parade ser- vice on Sunday next at 11 am. The full band and choir of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, supplemented by the organ, will take the service. Visitors will be welcome.

SUEZ CANAL. On the 25th inst. 12 vessels passed through the Suez Canal. Of these, 7 were British, 1 German, 1 Dutch, 1 Russian, and 1 Italian. The transit and passenger dues for the day amounted to 314,048.07 frs. The total transit and passenger dues collected from the 1st to that date on 319 vessels amounted to 8,329,118.81 frs.

COLLISION. A serious collision occurred this morning at 11 o'clock in Cherif Pasha- street between cab No. 1619 and a cyclist messenger in the service of Messrs. R. and O. Lindemann. The cycle was smashed and its rider thrown to the ground and injured in the temple. The victim was carried into Mac- Gregor's pharmacy, where first aid was given. The cabman was arrested.
Port Said is

PORT SAID BY THE SEA. doing its utmost to attract a share of holiday- makers in the summer months, and with this end in view two projects for building casinos are being studied, the one near the Minerva Baths and the other on the West jetty, fifty metres from De Lessep's statue. The latter is to be built on the lines of the Nice Casino, in the open sea.

THE BERLITZ METHOD. The principles, never departed from in any of the 226 Berlitz schools, are: 1. Exclusive use of the foreign language; 2. Direct association of the thought with the foreign tongue-direct perception; 3. Teaching the concrete by object lessons; 4. Teaching the abstract by association of ideas; 5. Teaching the grammar through examples. Every teacher teaches only his own language. Alexandria, 26, rue de l'Eglise Copte, Cairo, 1, Sharia Kamel Private trial lesson free. 24820-1
THE KHEDIVE.

His Highness attended prayers to-day at El Abasireh mosque, in the Ras-el-Tin quarter. The Governor was present. His Highness afterwards drove to Ras-el-Tin Palace, where he is spending the day. In the evening he re- tarns to Montazah.
OBITUARY.
CAPTAIN WAKEHAM.

We regret to announce the death, which took place at Liverpool yesterday, of Captain Wakeham, who was for many years agent at Alexandria of the Leyland Lane. The deceased was well-known and greatly respected during his residence here. We beg to tender our sympathy to his widow and family.
"YOU NEVER KNOW YOUR LUCK."

We publish in another column the advertise- ment of SAMUEL HECKSCHER SENR., OF HAMBURG. This house has acquired a high reputation for the prompt payment of amounts won by persons here and in all parts of the world. We would strongly recommend our readers to take particular notice of Mr. Heckscher's Announcement and try their luck to win A FORTUNE [ADVT.]
THE RAILWAY COMMISSION.
OFFICIAL STATEMENT.

As an erroneous idea seems to have arisen in some quarters as to the scope and objects of the recently-appointed Railway Commission we are authorised by the Ministry of Finance to make the following statement.

It has for some years past become more and more evident that the State Railways were unable to cope with the enormously increased traffic, and that sooner or later it would be imperatively necessary to incur some consider able expenditure in order to put them on s proper footing.

Now that the paramount claims of the Irriga tion and other Departments have been in part satisfied, and that the burden of taxation has greatly lightened, it may be hoped that the Government may before long find themselves in a financial position which will justify them in dealing with the Railway question and thereby meeting a universally-admitted want. A Commission, therefore, has been appointed charged with the duty of advising the Govern- ment as to the manner in which money could most usefully be employed in extending and developing the Railway system. Incidentally, they will propose any further reforms which their experience may suggest with a view of increasing the efficiency of the existing orga- nisation.
How far their recommendations will be put into practice must depend upon the amount of funds at the disposal of the Government.

The Commission consists of Lord Farrer, Mr. Oliver Bury, and Major Le Breton, all of whom are railway experts in their different lines of the very first rank. Lord Farrer, we may state, is a director of the Midland Railway Company and of the Underground Electric Railways Company of London, and in his younger days he served an apprenticeship in practical railway work on several of the English lines. Mr. Bury has been general manager of the Great Northern Railway since July, 1902, before which date he was general manager of the Buenos Ayres and Rosario Railway. He began his railway career with the London and South-Western Railway, and has had a varied experience both in England and South America. Major Le Breton has been an inspecting auditor under the Indian Government railway administration. He is already in Cairo engaged in completing his examination of the Railway accounts, a task with which he was entrusted by the President of the Railway Administration in the spring. The other two Commissioners are expected in November, and it is hoped that their recom- mendations will be in the hands of the Govern- ment by the beginning of the new year.
EGYPTIAN ARMY.
The Khedive has been most graciously pleased to approve of the promotion of El Bimbashi H. L. E. Fell, Sudan Civil Administration, to be Kaimakam.

Lieutenant A. W. Jennings Bramly, 20th Hussars, having reported his arrival in Khar- toum from Uganda on the 10th inst., is taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, from that date, with the rank of Bimbashi. He has been posted to the Cavalry.
The following transfers have been approved:- El Bimbashi H. M. Hutchinson, D.S.O., 11th Sudanese, to 9th Sudanese.
El Bimbashi B. H. S. Romilly, D.S.O., 9th Sudanese, to Camel Corps.
El Bimbashi D. C. E. ff Comyn, Camel Corps, to Sudan Civil Administration.
UPPER NILE EXPEDITION.

Major Powell-Cotton, of the Northumber and Fusiliers, is about to start on another expedition, the object of which is to explore the vast region lying between the Nile and the Zambesi. The journey will occupy about eighteen months, and the explorer will pass through that portion of the Congo territory which is very little known.
BRIDGE ADJUDICATIONS.

A correspondent writes:-I notice in your ssue of the 25th instant the result of the adjudication for the bridges on the Ibrahimieh Canal, but as not one single name is correct, perhaps you would like to correct same: Group I Mr. E H. should be Mr. E. H. Day
II Gandalay Gandolfi
III L. Santrasen L. Santspres
IV Spurgen L. Santaprès
[The errors were due to faulty transmission f the message from Cairo through the tele-
hone]
RAMADAN

During Ramadan the hours of work in the chools and kuttabs dependent on the Ministry s f Publje Instruction will be as follows In the schools, 9 a.m. to 3.30 p.m. In the kuttabs, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m. The time of each lesson is to be propor- onately reduced.

S. Dore, Bandmaster,
7. RAMLEH ELECTRIC RAILWAY.
CAUSE OF THE CABLE TROUBLE.
A correspondent writes:-

Some two and a half years ago the Alexandria and Ramleh Railway Company applied to the Egyptian Government for permission to lay a nd high-tension cable from Karmous to Chatby. ere The Government consulted with the Alex- ed dria Municipality and a plan was agreed be upon as to how the cable should be laid er and its depth, as well as the street align- nament which the cable was to follow. The company laid the cable according to these ra-instructions, and the work was duly inspected under M. Principe, and also inspected as by Mr. Graham, the then Administrator of the he Municipality. The work was approved by Mr. res Graham and M. Principe and found to be in m accordance with the instructions of the Muni- ad cipality. About the time the work was finished t. the Municipality decided to relay Menasce- ed road, and in some places, in so doing, reduced m-the level of the road to within ten centimetres ld of the cable. At the beginning of this year the company decided to lay a reserve cable y, from Karmous to Bulkeley so as to do away chwith any possibility of breakdowns or of stoppages. The comparty applied to the

Government for permission to lay this extra cable. In April, the company commenced to work from Bulkeley and had completed as far as the cemetery adjoining the Rosetta Gate, when work was stopped by the Municipality because, technically, the formal permission to lay the reserve cable had not been granted. This permission was not given until two months later, and the work d had to be suspended during this time. Surely it would be advisable if the Municipality obviated such mishaps by advising the company as to what roads they were going to take up Four or five times the cable has been found to be broken at places where the Municipality have been digging up the roads. If the control of the Ramleh Railway is to be handed over to the Municipality the poor company is sincerely to be pitied, for it will be far better under the Ministry of the Interior, which has a technical and capable electrical engineer to supervise. Only this week it has been discovered that the road at the back of the German Hospital is to be lowered forty centimetres. Therefore the company forced to relay the cable an extra forty centimetres. Owing to this, a few days ago, when the trenches were open for the purpose of lowering the cable, it was struck by lightning and was burnt to the extent of 150 metres. The Municipality is fully aware of all the 1 work that is being done. Why, then, does it not advise the company as to what it intends to do with the different streets through which the cable passes!
CATTLE PLAGUE

During the week ending yesterday,64 deaths have been reported throughout Egypt as due to bovine typhus. They are distributed as follows: Gouvernorats 2,, Lower Egypt 57, Upper Egypt 5, showing a diminution of 19 compared with the previous week.
Since the beginning of the epidemic the total of deaths amounts to 146,482, distributed as follows: Governorats 852, Lower Egypt 53,506, Upper Egypt 92,124.
One new locality (Tel Rezan) was reported infected last week. No animals were inoculated.
THE PILGRIMAGE.
300 pilgrims have arrived here from Cons-tantinople and are leaving for Jeddah via Suez.
ABBAS HELMY THEATRE
"ERNANI."

Owing probably to the meagre success which attended the first performance of this opera, the house last night was very poor. The performance, however, was successful and would have been excellent all-round but for the soprano part, which was somewhat lacking. Signa. Amelia Chiostro's style seems to begin with a soft and slight tone and end in screams. Sig. Pagani, as Ernani, was excellent, and met with enthusiastic applause. Sig. Borione, bary- tone, and Sig. Baldelli, bass, also played their parts satisfactorily.

ALHAMBRA THEATRE. The management was obliged last night to modify the printed programme owing to the indisposition of M. Marmier. Blanchette had to be substituted by Monsieur Badin and Bou- Louroche, the performance of which proved as successful as on the first occasion. M. La l'a Claveri was particularly good in the part of The audience was equally
Boulouroche
satisfied with the musical interlude. Mlle. Blanche d'Orange's songs met with general applause, as did M. Minart's excellent "creations."
STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The 8.8..Grecian Prince arrived in Manchester from Alexandria on Wednesday last.
The 8.8. Tuscan Prince, from Manchester, left Malta on Thursday and is due here on Monday co next, with passengers and general cargo.
